During locoregional anaesthesia, the local anaesthetics used act on nerve conduction by blocking voltage-dependent sodium channels. The action potential can no longer be conducted along the nerve fibre.

properties.question: What is the mechanism of action of local anaesthetics?
properties.option_a: The local anaesthetics work by blocking voltage-dependent sodium channels in the nerve fibre.
properties.option_b: Local anaesthetics work by blocking voltage-dependent calcium channels in the nerve fibre.
properties.option_c: The local anaesthetics work by blocking voltage-dependent potassium channels in the nerve fibre.
properties.option_d: Local anaesthetics work by blocking voltage-dependent potassium channels in the nerve fibre.
